title: [catalan]: change rama to branca
body: In Catalan, 'rama' refers to a tree branch with leaves, whereas 'branca' is, in addition, used in the more abstract way of subdivisions of a subject. In my opinion, 'branca' is a better translation of 'branch'.

title: Import files in chunks to prevent p4 from opening too many files.
body:
While doing a git p4 sync, I ran into a very large commit adding boost headers to the repository. In spite of me increasing the maximum open files limit, I kept on getting errors. Note that in my test I added the "Max files I can open" message to print some useful values. This output demonstrates the problem:

$ git p4 sync --max-changes 2
Performing incremental import into refs/remotes/p4/master git branch
Depot paths: //depot/
Import destination: refs/remotes/p4/master
Importing revision 42494 (50%)Max files I can open is 16384, readAtTime set to 1381, trying to read 1381 files
Perforce client error:
Partner exited unexpectedly.
Error from p4 print for //depot/extra/boost/preprocessor/seq/subseq.hpp: Date 2014/11/07 12:31:43:
Operation: flush2
Operation 'open for read' failed.
Database open error on pdb.lbr!
open for read: depot/depot/extra/boost/preprocessor/seq/subseq.hpp,v: Too many open files
open for read: depot/depot/extra/boost/preprocessor/seq/subseq.hpp,v: Too many open files


$ ulimit -Hn
32768
$ ulimit -Sn
16384

My understanding is that p4 tries to open all of the files it receives on the command line and thus hits the system limit. Running git-p4 with my fix solved this issue for me, I could get past the large commit and complete the sync without touching at the file limit.
I'm not very familiar with git-p4, so I hope the fix is correct in all circumstances! Also, I tried to dynamically obtain the max number of open files from the system, but I kept on getting the error and ended up hardcoding 256 as the limit. Most commits should include way fewer files than that anyways, so performance should still be more or less the same.

title: add dashdash to basename call for safety
body:
It is possible to have an argument to ``basename`` in git-sh-setup.sh that begins with a dash, causing an error. This commit adds a -- so that the argument won't break the call by being misinterpreted.

In the following example, the argument passed to ``basename`` will be "-bash":

    $ (source $(git --exec-path)/git-sh-setup require_work_tree)
    basename: illegal option -- b
    usage: basename string [suffix]
           basename [-a] [-s suffix] string [...] 

Environment:
OSX Yosemite
GNU bash, version 3.2.53(1)-release (x86_64-apple-darwin14)
git version 2.1.2

title: Add --skip-validation on xmlto on Make docs
body:
Trying to build the docs on my MacOS 10.9, and xmlto keeps failing because of validation issues.
After a bit of online research I saw other people having the same
issue. We should skip-validation for now until all xml docs are valid so people wont have the same issue.

This is the validation error when trying to `make doc`
```
make[2]: `GIT-VERSION-FILE' is up to date.
    XMLTO git-add.1
xmlto: /Users/arthurnn/dev/git/Documentation/git-add.xml does not validate (status 3)
xmlto: Fix document syntax or use --skip-validation option
I/O error : Attempt to load network entity http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd
/Users/arthurnn/dev/git/Documentation/git-add.xml:3: warning: failed to load external entity "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd"
                   "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd">
                                                                            ^
I/O error : Attempt to load network entity http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd
warning: failed to load external entity "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd"
validity error : Could not load the external subset "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.5/docbookx.dtd"
Document /Users/arthurnn/dev/git/Documentation/git-add.xml does not validate
make[1]: *** [git-add.1] Error 13
make: *** [install-doc] Error 2
```

title: git-new-workdir: Add Windows support
body:
The `contrib/workdir/git-new-workdir` script is tremendously useful, but does not work on Windows currently.

Adding Windows support was [discussed](https://groups.google.com/d/topic/msysgit/1z07lWg9Nts/discussion) in the past already.  Former attempts did not succeed, because

1. The [original attempt](https://github.com/joero74/git-new-workdir/blob/master/git-new-workdir.cmd) rewrote the script entirely, making it hard to maintain it in parallel to the existing.

2. The [revised attempt](https://github.com/dansmith65/git/blob/master/contrib/workdir/git-new-workdir-win) tried to embed Windows support into the existing script, but it does not account for (extremely weird) circumstances caused by UAC in combination with a deeply nested `runas` → `cmd` → cygwin/mingw32/msysgit `bash` → `cmd` → `mklink` process invocation call chain, which happens to break the ACL/file permissions of all links and files created by the script (effectively owned by no one, which is very rare but possible on Windows).

#### Proposed solution

1. Port the script into a native Windows `.cmd` script, in order to resolve 2) above.
2. Ensure a 1:1 port to facilitate ongoing maintenance.
3. Document why this is necessary.

The `git-new-workdir.cmd` script added here (1) not only works 100% identically to the existing, (2) it also contains the exact same structure, comments, code, and execution flow as the existing script.

title: Refactoring some long local export and test_must_fail sequences to the s...
body:
...horter single line version.

Occurrences of 
```
[...] &&
(
        VAR=VAL &&
        export VAR &&
        test_must_fail git command
) &&
[...]
```
in the test scripts have been replaced by
```
[...] &&
test_must_fail env VAR=VAL git comand && [...]
```
